node.name: Saturday Keynote
node.description: Saturday Keynote

user.name: Travis Oliphant
user.biography: Travis Oliphant is President, Chief Data Scientist & Co-Founder of Anaconda, Inc. (was called Continuum Analytics). Since 1997, he has worked extensively with Python for numerical and scientific programming, most notably as the primary developer of the NumPy package, and as a founding creator of the SciPy package. He is also the author of the definitive Guide to NumPy. As President and Chief Data Scientist of Continuum Analytics, Travis fosters the open source community and is dedicated to furthering the company’s open source projects. He also engages customers in all industries and helps guide technical direction of the company. He has served as a director of the Python Software Foundation and as a director of NumFOCUS which he founded in 2011.
user.title: Co-Founder of Anaconda, Inc.

node.name: Practical Packaging For Machine Learning Solutions
node.description:
In this talk we will cover the ways in which we can use Pythons packaging tools and best practices in order to make sharing our machine learning solutions easier.

We will cover the basics concepts and tools for Python packaging. Then we will introduce a few suggested schemes for how to package a machine learning project, followed by some tips and best practices.

We will wrap up with a few additional concerns related to creating quality projects and packages.

A good precursor to the talk is a blog that I wrote as a companion to this talk. It can be found at [blog.stevencutting.com](http://blog.stevencutting.com).

user.name: Steven Cutting
user.biography:
I have experience creating custom software and machine learning solutions for a variety of business clients.

I enjoy studying computer science, math, and data science.

I am passionate about creating reliable, high quality software projects.
user.title: Consultant

node.name: Small Potatoes: Microsimulation With Vivarium
node.description: Modeling complex systems is hard. Microsimulation can make it easier (but still hard). I’ll introduce microsimulation by using Vivarium, a Python simulation framework, to model plant growth and the effect of different ways of laying out a home garden on vegetable yields.

user.name: Alec Deason
user.biography: Alec Deason is a software engineer based in the Pacific Northwest where, as often as not, he wishes it would stop raining so he could garden.
user.title: Software Engineer at The Institute For Health Metrics and Evaluation

node.name: From Monolithic to Serverless with AWS Step Functions
node.description: Aside from proofs of concept, how are you realistically supposed to put Serverless into practice? Hear how Yelp has been moving a 10 year old codebase from tangled spaghetti toward serverless using AWS Step Functions (SFN). Learn SFN as infrastructure and how to incrementally move to Serverless.

user.name: Scott Triglia
user.biography: Scott Triglia is a Tech Lead at Yelp and loves making large backend systems reliable and effective. He helped architect Yelp's nearby recommendation engine and was the lead maintainer of business and search geocoding for years. These days he works on scaling up Yelp's commerce infrastructure to power services like food delivery, reservations, and advertiser subscriptions.
user.title: Software Engineer at Yelp

node.name: Sending email with Mailgun
node.description: Sending a single email is easy. Sending thousands, not so much. Join me to learn how to leverage the Mailgun API to send email from your Python applications.

user.name: Douglas Mendizábal
user.biography: Douglas is a senior software developer with 10+ years of development experience.  He is also the co-founder of the Alamo City Python Group in San Antonio, TX.
user.title: Senior Software Developer at Mailgun

node.name: Lunch
node.description: Food!

node.name: Python Metaprogramming for Mad Scientists and Evil Geniuses
node.description: The metaprogramming capabilities of Python provide an ideal environment for both mad scientists and evil geniuses! Those with insane or nefarious intent will learn the benefits of Python’s metaprogramming features. Do-gooders might also benefit.

user.name: Walker Hale IV
user.biography:
Walker Hale hase been using Python since the early 21st century and has become quite accustomed to its many core features. He particularly enjoys those features that allow the exploration of madness:

    >>> L = []
    >>> L.append(L)
    >>> L
    [[...]]
    >>> L[0]
    [[...]]
    >>> L is L[0]
    True

Walker came to Python when working at a small computer game company that he and three friends founded, and he then used Python to translate sections of game logic from Java to C++ for a Batman Begins game, in order to support different mobile platforms.

These days he works to support good scientists, because nobody will pay him to do evil. 😢
user.title: Lead Scientific Programmer at Baylor College of Medicine

node.name: Lessons Learned from Civic Hacking
node.description: Budgets, Housing, and Hurricanes. What do all of these things have in common? Civic Hacking. These were local problems that were tackled by a village of coding warriors.

user.name: Caroline Dikibo
user.biography: Caroline Dikibo is a Freelancer, MBA student, Environmental Scientist, and Fencing Coach but she always has time for Civic Hacking.
user.title: Web Developer at Houston Sword Sports

node.name: The Fastest FizzBuzz in the West: How to Make Your Own Programming Language
node.description:
In this talk, you'll learn how I built DIVSPL (Dustin Ingram's Very Special Programming Language), a tongue-in-cheek domain-specific language, which is particularly good for implementing FizzBuzz -- as quickly as possible.

We'll build DIVSPL with RPLY, an implementation of David Beazley's PLY (but with a "cooler" API) and make it compatible with RPython, a restricted subset of the Python programming language. Along the way, you'll learn about lexers, parsers, and grammars, and in the end, you'll know how to build your own language.

user.name: Dustin Ingram
user.biography:
I’m Dustin (aka [@di](https://github.com/di)), a software engineer at PromptWorks and director of our office in Austin, TX. I’m also a member of the Python Packaging Authority and have a master’s degree in Computer Science from Drexel University.

I have been a professional Python developer for more than ten years and have authored a number of small open-source projects including a number of Python packages.

I'm a member of the Python Packaging Working Group, the [Python Packaging Authority](https://github.com/orgs/pypa/people) and a maintainer of the [Warehouse project](https://pypi.org/).
user.title: Director && Software Engineer at PromptWorks

node.name: Fostering Technical Growth
node.description: As we progress from junior engineers to senior engineers, architects, and 10x engineers, how do we find the time to learn new technologies? How can our companies create environments conducive to technical growth? In this talk, we discuss culture, structure, and resources to foster technical growth.

user.name: April Neal
user.biography: April Neal is a software engineer at WP Engine where she spends her days deploying Django/Python/Rails/Golang/PHP applications into Heroku/AWS/GCP using DockerDockerDocker!/Kubernetes/Helm. She got her start in software at the Recurse Center in NYC. Before entering the world of software, April worked as a mechanical design engineer manufacturing superconducting wire and building communications systems for defense contractors. Along her path, she's taken note of the tiny things (and some not so tiny) that make culture great and your job enjoyable.

node.name: Big Data with Python & Google BigQuery
node.description: Learn how to load, manipulate, and extract terabytes of data with Python and BigQuery, Google Cloud’s Big Data SQL database. We’ll cover some ways we’re using it at Vox Media, why you might use it over other stores, and some tricks for getting up to speed quickly.

user.name: Jeff Kramer
user.biography:
Before building the Data Engineering team at Vox Media I ran the Big Data and the Cloud Foundry PaaS teams at HP Cloud. While at HP I also created the python based Cloud Agents serverless computing system and did a bunch of work on the Developer Experience team. Prior to HP I co-founded the Austin web consultancy Polycot, and led e-commerce, e-learning, CMS, CRM, and social network Rails and PHP projects for Specialized Bicycle Components, Specialty Sports Venture, the Texas Freedom Network, the Kapor Foundation, WorldChanging, and many others. In the stone age when the web was new I worked in the ISP industry and consulted for Whole Foods Market.

I’ve spoken about cloud management systems at ApacheCon, bots and other intelligent agents at SXSW, and Python Bottle, Cognitive Computing, and Slack Bots at prior PyTexas conferences.

I’m interested in old SGI, NeXT, and Macintosh computers, tech art, procedural generation, and immersive storytelling. I live in Austin with my wonderful wife and two great kids.
user.title: Director of Data Engineering at Vox Media

node.name: Building Python Applications with Docker
node.description: Containers are new, and Docker is a fast moving platform. Best practices evolve quickly, while examples in existing code-bases fall behind. I will cover best practices for delivering small, secure, reproducible containers of Python applications using recent Docker versions.

user.name: Moshe Zadka
user.biography: Moshe has been using open source software since 1995, and Python since 1998. He is a core contributor to Python and Twisted.
user.title: Site Reliability Engineer

node.name: Intro to GraphQL with Python
node.description: GraphQL is a new way to build APIs that are more flexible on the frontend and require less development time on the backend. This talk will introduce to you how and why you should use GraphQL and how to implement GraphQL with Python.

user.name: Paul Bailey
user.biography: I'm a web developer with a background in aerospace engineering. I help organize Python community events in Texas with PyWeb Houston and PyTexas. I'm obsessed with Web technology and created voice powered learning system called [Neutron Academy](https://www.neutron.academy/ ""). In addition to being a Web and aerospace geek, I'm a father of three and can cook a pretty mean pizza from scratch.

node.name: What is this machine learning thing, anyway?
node.description:
From self driving cars, to trippy psychedelic images, to beating world class players at board games—machine learning is all over the place. But, err, what is it?

This talk will introduce you to the basics of machine learning in a no-nonsense, practical way, without a lot of mathematical notation.

user.name: George Brocklehurst
user.biography: Originally from the UK, George moved to NYC via Stockholm. He works at thoughtbot, and builds things with Ruby and Python.
user.title: Developer at thoughtbot

node.name: Doubling deploy velocity with parallel stage environments
node.description:
Continuous deployment works great when there’s 3 devs…and not so much at 10.

At Cratejoy, we’ve built a simple, in-house solution using tools you’re already familiar with (Gitlab, Kubernetes, Docker) to orchestrate a complete staging environment for every branch. Learn how we ship code faster.

user.name: Josh Dover
user.biography: I am a generalist programmer, with a passion for balancing being practical with writing readable, well-tested code. Expertise in React, TensorFlow, Flask and more.
user.title: Lead Software Engineer at Cratejoy

node.name: Kubernetes after 18 months
node.description: Learn from our experience deploying both new and legacy applications to Kubernetes over the last 18 months. We’ve done everything from building greenfield microservices to migrating our existing core HTTP applications and video processing pipeline to Kubernetes, across different cloud vendors.

user.name: Thomas Stephens
user.biography:
Thomas Stephens is a software developer in Austin, Texas, working as a full stack developer at uStudio.

His day job involves writing Python and JavaScript, but he has written professionally in many languages, initially C and C++, with a detour to C#, with lots of scripting glue in Python, Ruby and, his first programming language love, Perl (they have since parted ways). He is always looking to learn new things, and try new tools, so he has dabbled in many more.
user.title: Software Engineer at uStudio

node.name: Performance Testing with Python and Locust
node.description: We often fail to consider the performance of our apps until they’re in production, but by then it may be too late! Run performance tests before they’re in production. I’ll describe how to integrate performance/load testing into your development process using Locust, Kubernetes, and Jenkins.

user.name: Michael Sluyter
user.biography: My undergrad degree was in music, but after coming to the realization that my odds of getting an orchestra gig were less than simultaneously winning the Powerball and getting hit by lightning, I took up my other great passion: typing! I did QA for a while after getting my masters in CS, and then moved into development about 10 yrs ago. I love tech and love learning new stuff. My goal is to die with a laptop opened to Hacker News by my side.
user.title: Sr. Software Engineer at WP Engine

node.name: Coffee, Code, and Community
node.description: Have you ever left a conference feeling invigorated and excited? Did you love the exposure to new ideas and sharing what you’ve been up to? Let me tell you about CoffeeOps it’s about making a community where you can find those feelings all the time.

user.name: Adam Glenn
user.biography: I've done everything from help desk to systems engineering to software development and worked at several cloud hosting companies including Rackspace and AWS. I believe the best teams focus on people first and tech second. Supporting your teammates, serving your customers, and being part of a community are just as important as growing as an engineer. These days I'm part of an amazing development team at Realself and together we help our users through some of the most important decisions of their lives.
user.title: DevOps Engineer

node.name: Lightning Talks
node.description: 5 minute lightning presentations. Open to all, [submit your talk here!](https://goo.gl/forms/Esn3HNGUTe65LR0j2)

node.description: Sunday Keynote

user.name: Ernest W. Durbin III
user.biography: Ernest is a contributor to the Infrastructure Team and Packaging Working Group member for The Python Software Foundation, Organizer for the Cleveland Python meetup, and upcoming Chair for PyCon US 2018 in Cleveland Ohio.
user.title: PyCon US 2018 Chair

node.name: Packaging voodoo revealed
node.description: Making software easy for other people to use is hard. We’ll talk about how to start a Python project to make it easy to share, how to create wheels and conda packages, and the critical technical details to consider to make sure that your packages work for as many people as possible.

user.name: Mike Sarahan
user.biography: Michael stumbled through an international career in science, eventually realizing programming was more fun and got him closer to sweet, sweet free childcare from family in Texas.  He specializes in building conda packages, and writing tools that make that easier.
user.title: Software Engineer at Anaconda, Inc.

node.name: MicroPython on an ESP8266
node.description: An ESP8266 is a $5 microcontroller with built-in wi-fi capability that can be used to automate things around your home and business. This includes reading sensors, turning on/off switches, controlling motors. This is made even more exciting by being able to use Python to control this!

user.name: Christopher Cooper
user.biography:
I have worked as an engineer, solution architect, and program/product manager in the enterprise software space for over 15 years.  I have a history of delivering business value to my customers, such as Ford, Johnson & Johnson, and Goodyear, through the implementation of software and technology related solutions to their most significant business problems.  Throughout this time I have found Python to be increasing applicable for tasks ranging from simple data manipulation to building Ford's DealerConnection web site platform that hosts customizable websites for Ford and Lincoln dealers throughout North America.

I have always had a hobbyist interest in embedded systems and low level software programming.  Since discovering the ESP8266 I have been intrigued by its amazing capabilities relative to its cost.  When I discovered that I could use Python to control the ESP8266, I was even more amazed and excited.

node.name: Introduction to Property-Based Testing with Hypothesis
node.description: Learn how to test better with less code using Hypothesis, a property-based testing library with batteries for popular ORMs.

user.name: Noah Seger
user.biography: Pythonista living in JavaScript exile.
user.title: Software Engineering Manager at Condé Nast

node.name: Literary Analysis via NLP: Topic Modeling Project Gutenberg
node.description: I’ve created a LDA topic model of the internet’s largest collection of public domain literature! Come learn about the data science behind the model, the computational infrastructure set up to support the calculations, and the insights to be gained from this investigation!

user.name: Rachel Brynsvold
user.biography:
Engineer-turned-data-scientist, with a love of all things Python and Data Science!  After getting my engineering degree, I moved to Austin and spent five years running a product reliability laboratory for an electronic products division at 3M, and then for two years I held a variety of technical and managerial positions at Austin startups and small businesses.  This summer, I decided to ‘make it official’ with data science by attending Galvanize’s Data Science Immersive program. 

When I’m not writing Python code to answer enigmatic data science questions, you’ll usually find me at home with my wonderful husband and two adorable but needy cats - knitting, or reading a book the old-fashioned way.
user.title: Recent Graduate of Galvanize Data Science Immersive

node.name: Lunch
node.description: Food!

node.name: Building Asynchronous Microservices with Tornado
node.description: Using Tornado to build microservices can improve response times and make the use of cloud resources more efficient. This talk will explain how to create a Tornado web application in Python 3 that asynchronously communicates with other services, including MongoDB, Redis, MySQL, and AWS.

user.name: Tim Jensen
user.biography: I've been a software engineer for about 20 years and have enjoyed working in many different programming languages. I started programming in Python about 18 months ago and have found it to be very satisfying. I love learning new things and also enjoy having opportunities to mentor other developers.
user.title: Senior Developer at uStudio, Inc.

node.name: Python and .NET: Why use both?
node.description: Python for .NET (pythonnet, Python.NET) allows two-way inter-operability between Python and CLR runtimes on Windows, Linux, OSX, and even Linux subsystem on Windows! This presentation is going to show how to use Python code from .NET and .NET assemblies from Python.

user.name: Denis Akhiyarov
user.biography: Denis Akhiyarov is Senior Consultant in Modeling at Wood, Intelligent Operations and faculty at North American University, where he is teaching a machine learning course to graduate students. He has been active in the Python and .NET communities since 2011.
user.title: Senior Consultant - Modeling

node.name: A Brief History of Coroutines in Python
node.description: With Python 3.6, coroutines became an core part of the Python language with async and await keywords, but cooperative multitasking had a rich history long before then. This talk walks through iterators, generators, generator delegation, “true” coroutines via async / await, and lots of sample code!

user.name: Josh Marshall
user.biography: I work at uStudio, a company I co-founded in 2010 that provides a cloud-based platform for online video management, distribution, and measurement. I've been lucky to work with a great team of smart folks building systems that scale for Fortune 500 companies and globally distributed audiences. I'm a big Python advocate, although I also enjoy learning new languages and technologies, and enjoy discussing things like TDD, pair programming, and user-friendly API design.
user.title: CTO at uStudio

node.name: The Reference Model : A Decade of Healthcare Predictive Analytics with Python
node.description: What is the life expectancy of a diabetic? What is the equivalent of Moore’s law for medical progress with respect to diabetic cardiovascular disease? How to interface with ClinicalTrials.Gov ? The talk will describe how python helped answer those questions after about a decade of work.

user.name: Jacob Barhak
user.biography:
Jacob Barhak has diverse international background in engineering, computing science, and disease modeling. He was educated at the Technion Israel Institute of Technology. From 2003 to 2006 he worked at an NSF Engineering Research Center at the University of Michigan focusing on inspection systems and personalization. From 2006 to 2012 he led the technical development of disease modeling tools for the Michigan Model for diabetes at the University of Michigan. The Reference Model for disease progression was self developed in 2012 and he currently pursues this development effort as an independent researcher. He is the developer of the Micro Simulation Tool (MIST).
His work was internationally exposed in multiple venues. His disease modeling work was repeatedly presented in multiple venues, including MODSIM, SummerSim, I/ITSEC, MSM/IMAG meeting.  Dr. Barhak is an advocate of non-blind scientific public review processes and active in organization work, including SummerSim and the Population Modeling working group.
user.title: Computational Disease Modeler

node.name: Reinforcement learning in Python
node.description: From AlphaGo beating the world’s top player to algorithms playing Atari games and Robots learning tasks and navigation, reinforcement learning has become the hottest area of AI. In this talk you will learn what RL is and how to use the most popular Python libraries.

user.name: Christine Doig
user.biography:
Christine is a Senior Product Manager and Data Scientist at Anaconda. She has over eight years’ experience in analytics, operations research and machine learning in a variety of industries, including energy, manufacturing and banking. At Anaconda, she worked on MEMEX, a DARPA-funded project helping stop human trafficking.

Christine holds an MS in Industrial Engineering from the Polytechnic University of Catalonia in Barcelona. She is an open source advocate and has spoken at PyData, EuroPython, SciPy, PyCon and many other conferences.
user.title: Senior Product Manager & Data Scientist at Anaconda

node.name: C for Yourself: Exploring Python Internals at the REPL
node.description: Completely ignoring how Python is implemented can get you into some nasty bugs. Having a basic mental model will protect you, and it doesn’t require reading CPython source code! I’ll show you a fun way to dissect common Python types down to the level of bytes, using the ctypes library and the REPL.

user.name: Robert Carrington
user.biography: Rob Carrington is a software developer at Q2 eBanking, where he works on large-scale data analytics. He holds an M.Sc. in Mathematical Logic from the Universiteit van Amsterdam.
user.title: Software Developer at Q2 eBanking

node.name: 0 → Kubernetes in Under an Hour
node.description:
Kubernetes is the hot new thing (for good reason), but it can be hard to know where to start with it.

This live walk-through gets a small python application running in Kubernetes locally, while introducing a few useful tools that make the overall experience easier.

user.name: Nicholas Mitchinson
user.biography:
My name is Nick Mitchinson. I have a Bachelors of Computer Science from the University of Waterloo, and am currently a Senior Software Engineer at Cratejoy.

Most of my time is spent focussing on performance, monitoring, and general systems engineering. I am an advocate of using the right tool for the job, service oriented architectures, and building atop stable (and open) software.

I'm really good at starting side projects, and really bad at finishing them.
user.title: Senior Software Engineer at Cratejoy

node.name: Slidoc: A Pythonic Learning Management System using Markdown and Google Sheets
node.description: Slidoc is an unconventional framework for a learning management system that combines slides and documents for courses, especially to teach Python. Markdown is used as the universal format for exams and interactive lectures. Google Sheets serves as back-end database and Tornado as the web server.

user.name: Ramalingam Saravanan
user.biography: Dr. R. Saravanan is currently a Professor of Atmospheric Sciences at Texas A&M University, College Station. Prior to that, he worked as a climate scientist at the National Center for Atmospheric Research, Boulder, Colorado. His research interests include the predictability of climate on seasonal to millennial timescales, and large-scale flow patterns in the atmosphere and the oceans. He has taught courses at both the undergraduate and graduate level, on the topics of atmospheric science, climatology, geophysical fluid dynamics, statistical methods, and computer programming. He also has a keen interest in the innovative use of computers in scientific research and more recently, in classroom teaching. His past computing projects include GraphTerm, a graphical terminal interface, Enigmail, a popular open-source add-on for email encryption in Thunderbird, and the Hyperslab Operator Suite (HOPS) for analyzing climate model data. Dr. Saravanan received his Master of Science in Physics from the Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, and his Ph.D. in Atmospheric and Oceanic Sciences from Princeton University. Following that, he carried out post-doctoral research at the Department of Applied Mathematics and Theoretical Physics, University of Cambridge.
user.title: Professor at Texas A&M University

node.name: MySQL 8—A New Beginning
node.description: MySQL 5.7 is great but MySQL 8 is a major redesign. It will have a true data dictionary which means you can have millions of tables within a schema. Windowing Functions, CTEs, roles, multi plane character support, and more important changes. Plus learn what happened to MySQL 6 and MySQL 7.

user.name: Dave Stokes
user.biography: Dave Stokes is a MySQL Community Manager for Oracle.  Previously he was the MySQL Certification Manager for MySQL AB and SUN.  He has worked for companies ranging alphabetically from the American Heart Association to Xerox and work ranging from Anti-submarine warfare to web developer.  And he really wonders how many people really, really read these conference biographies.
user.title: MySQL Community Manager

node.name: Closing Keynote
node.description: Closing Keynote

user.name: Paige Bailey
user.biography: Paige Bailey is a Sr. Cloud Developer Advocate at Microsoft specializing in machine learning and artificial intelligence. Paige’s education was focused on the earth sciences (geophysics, carbonate geology) and computer science (data analytics); and her previous work experience was geared toward drilling and completions optimization, data science, and geophysical plug-in development for the energy industry. When Paige is not sitting in front of glowing rectangular screens at work, she absolutely adores hiking / kayaking / mountain-biking around Texas’ glorious Green Belt; resuscitating Apple ][s; and (poorly!) attempting to play bass guitar. Personal passions are sustainable energy and climate change research; STEM education reform; and empowering local governments via data science.
user.title: Sr. Cloud Developer Advocate at Microsoft
